Description: Nixon administration imposed temporary export embargo on soybeans and cottonseed due to domestic inflation concerns and protein shortage
Notes: Short-lived but had far-reaching impacts; led to Japanese investment in Brazilian soybean industry

Description: Export embargo ended and contracts reinstated when soybean crop was larger than expected
Notes: Embargo lasted approximately 3 months

Description: Carter administration imposed grain embargo on Soviet Union in response to Afghanistan invasion
Notes: Part of broader economic sanctions; farmers bore brunt of sanctions

Description: Reagan administration ended Carter's grain embargo
Notes: Fertilizer d√©tente restored

Description: Trump administration initiated Section 301 tariffs on Chinese imports
Notes: Led to trade war with China

Description: China announced retaliatory tariffs on US agricultural products including soybeans in response to US tariffs
Notes: Major impact on US soybean farmers

Description: China implemented 25% tariff on $50 billion of US goods including soybeans
Notes: US soybean exports to China dropped dramatically

Description: US applied 25% tariff on $34 billion worth of Chinese imports
Notes: First round of tariff implementation

Description: Trump administration announced up to $12 billion in aid for farmers affected by trade war through Market Facilitation Program
Notes: Payments of $1.65/bushel for soybeans in 2018, $2.05/bushel in 2019

Description: Additional $16 billion of Chinese goods targeted (List 2)
Notes: Escalation of trade war

Description: Additional tariff on $200 billion of Chinese goods (List 3); rate increased to 25% in June 2019
Notes: Further escalation

Description: Temporary agreement at G20 Summit in Buenos Aires; China agreed to buy US agricultural products
Notes: Negotiations failed to reach final deal within 90 days

Description: US increased tariffs on $200 billion of Chinese goods from 10% to 25% after failed negotiations
Notes: Further deterioration of trade relations

Description: Trump announced 10% tariff on $300 billion of Chinese imports (Lists 4A and 4B)
Notes: China halted agricultural imports in response

Description: China halted imports of all American agricultural goods in response to new US tariffs
Notes: Major disruption to US agricultural exports

Description: China eliminated tariff increase on soybeans imposed in 2018
Notes: Part of negotiations toward Phase One deal

Description: Phase One Economic and Trade Agreement signed; China committed to purchasing additional $80 billion in US agricultural goods over 2020-2021
Notes: China committed to additional $12.5B in 2020 and $19.5B in 2021 over 2017 levels; China ultimately met only 57-59% of overall commitments, 83% of agricultural commitments

Tariff_Rate: 25% tariff remained but purchase commitments made
Description: Phase One agreement came into force; tariffs remained but China committed to increased purchases
Notes: Temporary stabilization but tariffs not removed

Description: Trump's second term began with threats of new tariffs on multiple countries including 10% on China; 25% on Mexico and Canada
Notes: Part of broader trade strategy

Description: Tariffs implemented invoking national emergency over immigration and drug trafficking
Notes: Mexico and Canada received temporary pause; China tariffs remained

Tariff_Rate: 15% on key farm products; 10% on soybeans
Description: China imposed 15% tariffs on chicken/pork/soybeans/beef; 10% on crude oil and agricultural machinery
Notes: Additional pressure on US agriculture

Description: China-specific tariff increased to 20%
Notes: Escalation continued

Description: Steel and aluminum tariffs (25% on both) implemented after 30-day pause ended
Notes: Removed previous exemptions

Description: China suspended soybean import privileges for three US companies (CHS Inc.; Louis Dreyfus; EGT)
Notes: Market access further restricted

Description: White House announced sweeping tariffs on 50+ countries; combined tariff rate of 54% on Chinese goods
Notes: Major escalation of trade war

Description: China responded with additional 34% levy on top of existing 10% tariffs; total soybean tariff reached 44%
Notes: Combined with earlier tariffs, US agricultural exports faced 44-49% tariffs

Description: China's retaliatory tariffs took effect; soybeans at 44%; other products 44-49%
Notes: Over $15.7 billion in US agricultural exports affected

Description: New trade framework announced; China agreed to purchase 12 MMT soybeans Nov-Dec 2025; 25 MMT annually 2026-2028; suspension of March 2025 retaliatory tariffs
Notes: Agreement includes resumption of sorghum and hardwood log imports; tariff details and implementation ongoing as of Nov 2025
